body:
Hi @Jens-G ,
I think that this addresses the issues you've identified. I tested with this file:

```
namespace go go_breakage

enum Weekday {
  SUNDAY ( weekend = "yes" ),
  MONDAY,
  TUESDAY,
  WEDNESDAY,
  THURSDAY,
  FRIDAY,
  SATURDAY ( weekend = "yes" )
} (foo.bar="baz")

typedef map< string, Weekday> dayMapType

struct OptionEntries {
  1 : optional Weekday dayOne = Weekday.TUESDAY
  2 : required Weekday dayTwo
  3 : optional map< string, Weekday> dayMapOne
  4 : optional dayMapType dayMapTwo
}

struct ConfigOption {
  1 : required string OptionID
  2 : optional string Display
  3 : required OptionEntries Entries
  4 : optional string SelectedID
}

typedef list< ConfigOption>  ConfigOptions

struct ConfigGroup {
  1 : required string GroupID,
  2 : optional string Display,
  4 : optional ConfigOptions Options,
  5 : optional bool IsError
}

typedef list< i32 > IntArray

struct SomeEntry {
  2 : required string ID
  6 : optional IntArray SeriesIDs
}
```

I will write some basic automated tests before merging, but I want to make sure that you're okay with the approach first since I have so little time for this! Thanks,
Ben

I tried to merge the changes with current trunk. Unfortunately, I got a number of conflicts, as there have been some other (necessary) fixes in the meantime. I'm not sure, how to continue. Should I try to resolve them on my own or do you want to do this? What would you suggest?

Could you tell me which branch to merge with? I tried to pull master the
other day and didn't see anything there... I'm happy to try and resolve
things. Or you could just try my branch as-is (i.e., without merging) and
verify that things seem to be working?

Your call.

On Wed, Dec 4, 2013 at 3:32 PM, Jens Geyer notifications@github.com wrote:

> I tried to merge the changes with current trunk. Unfortunately, I got a
> number of conflicts, as there have been some other (necessary) fixes in the
> meantime. I'm not sure, how to continue. Should I try to resolve them on my
> own or do you want to do this? What would you suggest?
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/62#issuecomment-29857334
> .

Ok, I'll try your branch as it is at the weekend and let you know. 

I tried to merge with Thrift master, of course. :-) ;Most recent patch has been https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2278, but there were a few more, also in the compiler code. 

BTW, did you try the Go 1.2 release? I'm still at 1.1, but I think I'll give that one a try too.
I forgot: There are two more patches in the Go area which I will commit within the next days, unless anyone vetoes: THRIFT-2280 and THRIFT-2281

Ah, I stupidly forgot that I was working off of a fork we made of the main thrift repo -- I was wondering why there hadn't been any activity!

I can try to resolve the merge if you want to wait fro that... Obviously I'd have to do so anyway, one way or the other...

Hey Jens,
I'll deal with the merge failures myself... I reproduced them easily and
now have to fix some bugs introduced as a result. I'll let you know when
I'm done! Thanks,
Ben

The good news first: I had absolutely not a single problem compiling my >1000 lines of IDL and get my smallish test program to work.

But, phew ... it makes handling with data structures a lot more complex. 
Now I have to write:

```
fmt.Printf("Building request data ...\n")
request := S4P.NewGetTranslationData()
request.Base_ = S4P.NewApiRequest()
request.Base_.RequestID = new(string)
*request.Base_.RequestID = "tester"
request.Base_.SessionID = new(string)
*request.Base_.SessionID = "mysessionid"
request.Language = new(string)
*request.Language = "FRENCH"
request.ResIDs = new(S4P.StringArray)
*request.ResIDs = make([]string, 1, 1)
(*request.ResIDs)[0] = "Mist"
```

where I wrote before

```
fmt.Printf("Building request data ...\n")
request := S4P.NewGetTranslationData()
request.Base_ = S4P.NewApiRequest()
request.Base_.RequestID = "tester"
request.Base_.SessionID = "mysessionid"
request.Language = "FRENCH"
request.ResIDs = make([]string, 1, 1)
request.ResIDs[0] = "Mist"
```

What am I doing wrong?

This is one of my least favorite aspects of Go programming... namely, that there's no way to allocate a constant on the heap in a single expression.

See the following:

  http://play.golang.org/p/wDJT7GtGRX

Note that things are a little less bad if you're assigning variables rather than constants, though:

  http://play.golang.org/p/5LWiZSgbBC

... and, in practice, that latter case is a common one.

So, what to do? Well, protobufs have exactly the same problem and for all of the same reasons: they want to use Go structs to represent the IDL structs, yet there's this maddening thing about expressing pointers to compile-time constant values. Look at what they do:

  https://code.google.com/p/goprotobuf/source/browse/README#147

Let me know how you'd like to proceed. I know that in my own project we just bit the bullet and created a base package called "ptr" that takes essentially every builtin Go type and creates a pointerizing function... Int32Ptr, Int64Ptr, IntPtr, BoolPtr, and so on and so forth. Argh!

I vote for adding some of these helpers to https://github.com/apache/thrift/tree/master/lib/go/thrift... what do you think? We could take things further and have _all_ fields of all structs -- required, optional, whatever -- be pointers. Just for consistency's sake. But I don't feel strongly about it, and the above is not strictly necessary, of course. (Though it would be easier to verify if a required field had not been set properly by the user)
:shipit:
Hi @Jens-G ... please take a look. I added central support for pointerization of base types and generated support for pointerization of user-defined enums and typedefs.

Very nice, works quite well. Good work! 

As expected, I just had to add a bunch of nil checks. Then I extended my test case somewhat and run into some errors again, but this time I very much suspect the JSON transport. If that's the case we can fix that separately. I have to dig a little deeper to find out. I'll let you know.

Good to hear! Please let me know what else (if anything) you require of me before this is merge-able. Thanks again for your help,
Ben

PS: My team may be interested in implementing a proper HTTP server for thrift-golang. (To supplement the socket server that's there now) Do you know if someone's already working on that? If not, perhaps it could happen over the holidays or something.

I was able to locate the remaining problems I had. 

One of then is indeed relatwed JSON, someone obviosly didn't check his assumptions - https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2288.

Before I was able to uncover that one, I had to fix certain places in the generator, where error handling stuff was lacking printf() args. One of my constant mantras is "_error handling is a feature_", because people (myself included) tend to forget that things go wrong in the real world. Can I send you a patch directly or do I have to fork the project first?
whatever is easiest for you!
(oh, and I have incorporated your patch)

Hi Ben,

Thank you, and Iâ€™ll look at it tomorrow as soon as I have the time. It is about 1 hr after midnight over here ... :-) 

> Sit back and wait 

For legal reasons, the currently active rules enforce us to ask for a patch added to JIRA by you. By adding the patch to the JIRA ticket, you are granting the ASF the rights on it. Thatâ€™s why we currently do not accept pull requests for integration into master. Sorry for the inconveniences.

http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute

Best regards,
JensG
Ah, lawyers, right... Okay, done!
Committed as acdac816659c88e7b8b601b4ad42dc43bf7d48e2.

@emchristiansen this is just a mirror of the apache repo, and i'm told they don't accept pull requests due to licensing issues. 

contribution process is documented here: http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute/

Wow, attach a diff to a JIRA issue?!?
I guess they don't want contributions :(

however, there was a patch and i committed this: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2185
please close this pull request.
-r

I'm right now reviewing this. 
If build and test goes through (and so far I have no doubts) and if you [could put the patch](http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute/) as a ticket into [JIRA](http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT), I'd be happy to commit this fix. A dedicated testcase would be good, though.

Thank you!

Done! https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2311

It seems that the issue isn't as serious as I thought -- not all exception-throwing methods are affected. Invalid code is generated only when an exception variable name is a go keyword (`error` in my case).

LGTM, thanks. If you [make a patch out of it](http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute), I can commit it. By the way, the title of the patch does not reflect the content accurately. The patch is ok, but it does something different than what is announced by the title.

Hi fwang2002,

maybe I have to explain. For legal reasons, we need the patch uploaded into JIRA. I can look at a pull request, I can comment it, etc. but I can't commit it. Sorry.

I can do the review, but to be finally accepted and committed into the code base, we need a [JIRA ticket](http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute). 

Some more details regarding the "why" can be found in [this mailing list post](http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/thrift-dev/201310.mbox/%3CCANyrgvc2e_8wzDWoJ=OToO4dEpR9uHipevn2NUh93gFT9RV9Hg@mail.gmail.com%3E).

Is that OK with you?
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2339
@JSSTR Thank you for submitting the jira issue. Closing this pr as further discussions on this should continue on that ticket

testing reply@

Hi Adam, thanks for the request.
Do you think this new parameter is really necessary?
I would take this change more as a direct improvement since it wouldn't break existing code, would it?
Additional parameters make testing harder...

Hi Henrique - I think this new parameter would be required - the patch is not breaking existing code, however it may reveal issues in existing applications (currently the deserialization delivers always newly allocated objects, but when the re-use is switched on, the application needs to remember to properly "clean" all storage objects, otherwise subsequent deserializations will be added on the top of previous ones. 
So I think enabling this feature by default for all applications may create headache.

in this case we should have at least unit-tests demonstrating, and testing, the correct usage. 
What do you think?

unfortunatelly you are right ;)
I can create updated unit test based on existing one for java - but I'm not familiar enough with Thrift to judge what I should use as the base, so I would need some guidance.

That would be great Adam!
Maybe someone else has a better idea, but you can have a look on https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/lib/java/build.xml  <target name="generate">
perhaps generate ThriftTest.thrift with a different "-out" folder and run the tests there?
Cheers!

ok, I added unit tests for this new option
I also updated the Export/Import entries in the manifest (via build.xml), so the bundle (jar) is now more OSGi friendly.

please let me know how do you like these changes.
Duplicate of THRIFT-1743 (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-1743)
Create https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2442 for this pull request.
On Windows, you should call TWinsockSingleton::create() at an opportune time in your code.  This can be found in the thrift/windows/TWinsockSingleton.h header.
This is what the pull request fixes.

Would this work if you have multiple servers simultaneously opened in the same process?
I also don't like the idea of having to start it manually, specially because it's a windows only requirement.
It would be really nice to have it automatically started.
I'm using multiple servers running in seperate threads and I call the create method only once in my application.

This should go in one of three directions:
Option 1: completely abandon this path
Option 2: Be more thorough in calling TWinsockSingleton::create().  You're calling it for serverSocket::listen, but you aren't doing anything on client creation.  I don't particularly care for this approach, because it adds overhead that isn't strictly required.
Option 3: Make a platform abstraction for TWinsockSingleton::create() that can be called on all OSes.  It would be a no op on posix platforms, but at least then you don't need ifdefs in your code.
There is no ticket yet, right?
not yet

I tried the above patch in my application using multiple servers and I didn't notice any issues with calling `TWinsockSingleton::create()` multiple times. Even leaving the old code that calls `TWinsockSingleton::create()` while initializing the application in causes no problem.

I would vote to go with option 2 as it makes the usage of thrift easier.

Hey @djwatson, thanks for another patch, really appreciate your contributions back to Apache Thrift. looking at it quickly config check are good, compiler looks good, files added to dist (thanks, this often gets missed) and lib with test cases look good, if you could address the following I think this can get merged in
- Facebook license headers on some of the files, needs to be replaced with the Apache license version 2.0 headers
- Not that big a deal, but Andrews is assigned one of the leftover TODO tags, just need to add the note on whats needed and remove his id from it

Thanks again
-Jake
These should both be fixed - updated all the headers I found to apache (let me know if I missed any).  Updated the TODO with description and remove name

There's a log of a failure in Thrift's nightly build.

https://builds.apache.org/job/Thrift/1123/console

tutorial/shared.thrift and tutorial/tutorial.thrift end up causing problems.  The relevant Makefile.am appears to be building in the _types.cpp.  I have not looked at the generated source.  My current suspicion is that the "final" attribute check is causing problems, but that is currently just a hunch.

Hi Dave,
This destructor is only for structs, isn't it?
The ld error is for *_presult and *_pargs

@djwatson Yes, my _types.cpp is linked in.
But as @henrique mentioned _presult and _pargs destructor's are not generated and thus linker gives error.
Thanks guys, fix: https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/98

Thanks for the patch. I'm not so sure if introducing a number of dependencies plus another new test project by a coup de main is such a great idea, especially if we compare all those changes to the net size of the patch itself. Did you run the tests on all relevant platforms or only with Visual Studio? I'm just asking, because that's important.

I only ran the tests in VS, but I can certainly try them out in MonoDevelop on my mac when I get a chance. I figured that since NUnit and Moq are pretty standard for unit testing in the .NET world, and that the test project wouldn't be distributed with the library (and therefore those dependencies won't be distributed either) it would be ok. Does that reasoning make sense?

Cheers for committing the fix though.

Hi Beat, 
is there a JIRA ticket for it? If not, could you create one? 
Thanks,
JensG

Hi,

The problem should already be solved (in a better way, btw) by [THRIFT-2495](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2495), so I guess that this pull request has become  somewhat obsolete. If not, please reopen [THRIFT-2495](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2495) and add a test case. 

Appreciating your contribution,
JensG

Great! 

Could you please create a [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT) ticket and have a look at the [contrib guide](http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute), just to make sure everything is in place? 

Looking forward to review it!

Why are you reformatting the whole code? No wonder the patch is that big. Introduced lots of new Indy dependencies (the existing one is already bad enough). Lots of strange type changes without any obvious reason. Broken D2010 and XE compatibility. The infamous `__history` folder included. And on, and on. Could you please explain why all that stuff is necessary?

Thanks a lot Pascal!
It's looking good. I have also added a sub-section to the lib/js/README.md, please fell free to add more info or a simple example of usage there. Looking forward to seeing the node.js support ;)
